{{tone|date=October 2011}} [[Image:Arecibo message bw.svg|thumb|upright=.6|A representation of the 1679-[[bit]] [[Arecibo message]].]] '''Active SETI''' ('''Active Search for Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence''') is the attempt to send messages to intelligent extraterrestrial life. Active SETI messages are usually sent in the form of radio signals. Physical messages like that of the [[Pioneer plaque]] may also be considered an active SETI message. Active SETI is also known as '''METI''' ('''Messaging to Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence'''). The term METI was coined by Russian scientist [[Alexander Zaitsev (scientist)|Alexander Zaitsev]], who denoted the clear-cut distinction between Active SETI and METI: {{cite arXiv |last1=Zaitsev |first1=A. |title=Messaging to Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence |year=2006 |eprint=physics/0610031 }}{{cite news |last=Johnson |first=Steven |title=Greetings, E.T. (Please Don’t Murder Us.) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/28/magazine/greetings-et-please-dont-murder-us.html |date=28 June 2017 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628101941/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/28/magazine/greetings-et-please-dont-murder-us.html |archivedate=28 June 2017 |df= }}
The science known as [[SETI]] deals with searching for messages from aliens. METI deals with the creation and transmission of messages to aliens. Thus, SETI and METI proponents have quite different perspectives. SETI scientists are in a position to address only the local question “does Active SETI make sense?” In other words, would it be reasonable, for SETI success, to transmit with the object of attracting ETI’s attention? In contrast to Active SETI, METI pursues not a local and lucrative impulse, but a more global and unselfish one – to overcome the Great Silence in the Universe, bringing to our extraterrestrial neighbors the long-expected annunciation '''“You are not alone!”'''
In 2010, [[Douglas Vakoch|Douglas A. Vakoch]] of the [[SETI Institute]] addressed concerns about the validity of Active SETI alone as an experimental science by proposing the integration of Active SETI and Passive SETI programs to engage in a clearly articulated, ongoing, and evolving set of experiments to test various versions of the [[Zoo Hypothesis]], including specific dates at which a first response to messages sent to particular stars could be expected. {{cite conference |last1 = Vakoch |first1 = D. A. |year = 2010 |title = Integrating Active and Passive SETI Programs: Prerequisites for Multigenerational Research |book-title=Proceedings of the Astrobiology Science Conference 2010 |url = http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/abscicon2010/pdf/5213.pdf |page = 5213 |bibcode = 2010LPICo1538.5213V |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140809184104/http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/abscicon2010/pdf/5213.pdf |archivedate = 2014-08-09 |df = }} On 13 February 2015, scientists (including [[Douglas Vakoch]], [[David Grinspoon]], [[Seth Shostak]], and [[David Brin]]) at an annual meeting of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]], discussed Active SETI and whether transmitting a message to possible intelligent [[extraterrestrial life|extraterrestrials]] in the [[Cosmos]] was a good idea;{{cite news |url=https://phys.org/news/2015-02-cosmos-risky.html |title=Should We Call the Cosmos Seeking ET? Or Is That Risky? |date=13 February 2015 |website=Phys.org |last=Borenstein |first=Seth |accessdate=14 February 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214001713/http://phys.org/news/2015-02-cosmos-risky.html |archivedate=14 February 2015 |df=}}{{cite news |last=Ghosh |first=Pallab |title=Scientists in US are urged to seek contact with aliens |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-31442952 |date=12 February 2015 |work=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=12 February 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213064250/http://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-31442952 |archivedate=13 February 2015 |df= }} That same week, a statement was released, signed by many in the SETI community including [[Berkeley SETI Research Center]] director [[Andrew Siemion]], advocating that a "worldwide scientific, political and humanitarian discussion must occur before any message is sent".{{cite web |author=Various |title=Regarding Messaging To Extraterrestrial Intelligence (METI) / Active Searches For Extraterrestrial Intelligence (Active SETI) |url=http://setiathome.berkeley.edu/meti_statement_0.html |date=13 February 2015 |work=[[University of California, Berkeley]] |accessdate=14 February 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214142331/http://setiathome.berkeley.edu/meti_statement_0.html |archivedate=14 February 2015 |df= }} On 28 March 2015, an essay with a different point of view was written by [[Seth Shostak]] and published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news |last=Shostak |first=Seth |authorlink=Seth Shostak |title=Should We Keep a Low Profile in Space? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/28/opinion/sunday/messaging-the-stars.html |date=28 March 2015 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=29 March 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328220610/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/28/opinion/sunday/messaging-the-stars.html |archivedate=28 March 2015 |df= }} ==Rationale for METI== In the paper [https://arxiv.org/abs/1105.0910 Rationale for METI], transmission of the information into the Cosmos is treated as one of the pressing needs of an advanced civilization. This view is not universally accepted, and it does not agree to those who are against the transmission of interstellar radio messages, but at the same time are not against SETI searching. Such duality are called [https://arxiv.org/abs/physics/0611283 The SETI Paradox]. ==Radio message construction== The lack of an established [[communications protocol]] is a challenge for METI. First of all, while trying to synthesize an Interstellar Radio Message (IRM), we should bear in mind that Extraterrestrials will first deal with a physical phenomenon and, only after that, perceive the information. At first, ET's receiving system will detect the radio signal; then, the issue of extraction of the received information and comprehension of the obtained message will arise. Therefore, above all, the Constructor of an IRM should be concerned about the ease of signal determination. In other words, the signal should have maximum openness, which is understood here as an antonym of the term security. This branch of signal synthesis can be named '''anticryptography'''. To this end, in 2010, Michael W. Busch created a general-purpose binary language, {{cite conference |last1=Busch |first1=M. W. |last2=Reddick |first2=R. M. |year=2010 |title=Testing SETI Messages Design |book-title=Proceedings of the Astrobiology Science Conference 2010 |url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/abscicon2010/pdf/5070.pdf |arxiv=0911.3976 |bibcode=2010LPICo1538.5070B |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HnXxFGgj?url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/abscicon2010/pdf/5070.pdf |archivedate=2013-07-01 }} later used in the [[Lone Signal]] project {{cite web |website=Lone Signal |title=Message Encoding – But, Can They Read It? |url=http://www.lonesignal.com/about/encoding |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130624203807/https://www.lonesignal.com/about/encoding |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 June 2013 |accessdate=7 July 2013 }} to transmit crowdsourced messages to extraterrestrial intelligence. {{cite web |website=Lone Signal |title=Recent Beams |url=http://www.lonesignal.com/ |accessdate=7 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130707124938/http://www.lonesignal.com/ |archivedate=7 July 2013 |df= }} Busch developed the coding scheme and provided Rachel M. Reddick with a test message, in a blind test of decryption. Reddick decoded the entire message after approximately twelve hours of work. This was followed by an attempt to extend the syntax used in the [[Lone Signal]] hailing message to communicate in a way that, while neither mathematical nor strictly logical, was nonetheless understandable given the prior definition of terms and concepts in the hailing message. {{cite web |last1=Chapman |first1=C. R. |title=Extending the syntax used by the Lone Signal Active SETI project |url=http://sites.google.com/site/lonesignalactiveseti/ |website=Lone Signal Active SETI |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IqrYp0fX?url=https://sites.google.com/site/lonesignalactiveseti/ |archivedate=13 August 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}
{{cite web |title=Lone Signal & Jamesburg Earth Station Technologies - Technical Setup |url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/lonesignal-prod-web/Lone+Signal+Technical+Setup_06042013.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ik4qwRQ5?url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/lonesignal-prod-web/Lone+Signal+Technical+Setup_06042013.pdf |archive-date=2013-08-09 }} Also characteristics of the radio signal such as wavelength, type of polarization, and modulation have to be considered. Over galactic distances, the interstellar medium induces some scintillation effects and artificial modulation of electromagnetic signals. This modulation is higher at lower frequencies and is a function of the sky direction. Over large distances, the depth of the modulation can exceed 100%, making any METI signal very difficult to decode. ===Error correction=== In METI research, it is implied that any message must have some redundancy, although the exact amount of redundancy and message formats are still in great dispute. Using ideograms, instead of binary sequence, already offers some improvement against noise resistance. In faxlike transmissions, ideograms will be spread on many lines. This increases its resistance against short bursts of noise like radio frequency interference or interstellar scintillation. One format approach proposed for interstellar messages was to use the product of two prime numbers to construct an image. Unfortunately, this method works only if all the bits are present. As an example, the message sent by [[Frank Drake]] from the [[Arecibo Observatory]] in 1974 did not have any feature to support mechanisms to cope with the inevitable noise degradation of the interstellar medium. Error correction tolerance rates for previous METI messages * Arecibo Message (1974) : 8.9% (one page) * Evpatoria message (1999) : 44% (23 separate pages) * Evpatoria message (2003) : 46% (one page, estimated) ====Examples==== The 1999 [[Cosmic Call]] transmission was far from being optimal (from our terrestrial point of view) as it was essentially a monochromatic signal spiced with a supplementary information. Additionally, the message had a very small modulation index overall, a condition not viewed as being optimal for interstellar communication. * Over the 370,967 bits (46,371 bytes) sent, some 314,239 were “1” and 56,768 were “0”—5.54 times as many 1's as 0's. * Since [[frequency shift keying]] modulation scheme was used, most of the time the signal was on the “0” frequency. * In addition, “0” tended to be sent in long stretches (white lines in the message). ==Realized projects== These projects have targeted stars between 17 and 69 light-years from the Earth. The exception is the [[Arecibo message]], which targeted [[globular cluster M13]], approximately 24,000 light-years away. The first message to reach its destination will be [[RuBisCo Stars]], which should reach [[Teegarden's star]], a [[brown dwarf]] in 2021. * [[The Morse Message (1962)]]{{cite web|url=http://www.lightspeedmagazine.com/nonfiction/you-never-get-a-seventh-chance-to-make-a-first-impression-an-awkward-history-of-our-space-transmissions/ |author=Genevieve Valentine |title=You Never Get a Seventh Chance to Make a First Impression: An Awkward History of Our Space Transmissions |work=Lightspeed Magazine |date=March 2011 |accessdate=9 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160524123653/http://www.lightspeedmagazine.com/nonfiction/you-never-get-a-seventh-chance-to-make-a-first-impression-an-awkward-history-of-our-space-transmissions/ |archivedate=24 May 2016|df=}} * [[Arecibo message]] (1974) * [[Cosmic Call]] 1 (1999) * [[Teen Age Message]] (2001) * Cosmic Call 2 (2003) * [[Across the Universe (message)|Across the Universe]] (2008) * A Message From Earth (2008) * [[Hello From Earth]] (2009) * [[RuBisCo Stars]] (2009){{cite web|url=http://www.centauri-dreams.org/?p=10283 |title="RuBisCo Stars" and the Riddle of Life |date=18 November 2009 |author=Paul Gilster |website=Centauri Dreams |accessdate=9 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118144520/http://www.centauri-dreams.org/?p=10283 |archivedate=18 January 2017 |df=}} * [[Wow! Message]] |} ==Potential risk== {{see also |Search for extraterrestrial intelligence#Debate}} Active SETI has been heavily criticized due to the perceived risk of revealing the location of the Earth to alien civilizations, without some process of prior international consultation. Notable among its critics is scientist and science fiction author [[David Brin]], particularly in his article "expose."{{cite web |url=http://lifeboat.com/ex/shouting.at.the.cosmos |title=Shouting at the Cosmos |author=David Brin |date=September 2006 |orig-year=last updated July 2008 |website=Lifeboat Foundation |accessdate=9 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170307223116/http://lifeboat.com/ex/shouting.at.the.cosmos|archivedate=7 March 2017|df=}} However, Russian and Soviet radio engineer and astronomer [[Alexander L. Zaitsev]] has argued against these fears.{{cite journal |title=Sending and searching for interstellar messages |first=Alexander L. |last=Zaitsev |date=September 2008 |journal=Acta Astronautica |volume=63 |issue=5–6 |pages=614–617 |via=ScienceDirect |doi=10.1016/j.actaastro.2008.05.014 |arxiv = 0711.2368 |bibcode = 2008AcAau..63..614Z }}{{cite journal |url=http://jre.cplire.ru/jre/may08/2/text_e.html |title=Detection Probability of Terrestrial Radio Signals by a Hostile Super-civilization |author=Alexander L. Zaitsev |journal=Journal of Radio Electronics |issue=5 |year=2008 |accessdate=9 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118154523/http://jre.cplire.ru/jre/may08/2/text_e.html |archivedate=18 January 2017|df=}} Indeed, Zaitsev argues that we should consider the risks of not reaching out to extraterrestrial civilizations.{{cite web |url=http://www.setileague.org/editor/meti.htm |title=Making a Case for METI |author1=Alexander Zaitsev |author2=Charles M. Chafer |author3=Richard Braastad |website=SETI League |accessdate=9 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170221134306/http://www.setileague.org/editor/meti.htm|archivedate=21 February 2017 |df=}} To lend a quantitative basis to discussions of the risks of transmitting deliberate messages from Earth, the SETI Permanent Study Group of the International Academy of Astronautics{{cite web |url=http://iaaseti.org |title=Overview |website=International Academy of Astronautics – SETI Permanent Committee |accessdate=9 April 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510081227/http://iaaseti.org/|archivedate=10 May 2017 |df=}} adopted in 2007 a new analytical tool, the [[San Marino Scale]].{{cite web |url=http://iaaseti.org/smiscale.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071208183315/http://iaaseti.org/smiscale.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=8 December 2007|title=The San Marino Scale |website=International Academy of Astronautics – SETI Permanent Committee |accessdate=9 April 2017}} Developed by Prof. [[Ivan Almar]] and Prof. [[H. Paul Shuch]], the San Marino Scale evaluates the significance of transmissions from Earth as a function of signal intensity and information content. Its adoption suggests that not all such transmissions are created equal, thus each must be evaluated on a case-by-case basis before establishing blanket international policy regarding Active SETI. In 2012, Jacob Haqq-Misra, Michael Busch, Sanjoy Som, and Seth Baum argued that while the benefits of radio communication on Earth likely outweigh the potential harms of detection by extraterrestrial watchers, the uncertainty regarding the outcome of contact with extraterrestrial beings creates difficulty in assessing whether or not to engage in long-term and large-scale METI. {{cite journal | last1 = Haqq-Misra | first1 = J. | last2 = Busch | first2 = M. W. | last3 = Som | first3 = S. M. | last4 = Baum | first4 = S. D. | year = 2013 | title = The benefits and harm of transmitting into space | journal = Space Policy | volume = 29 | pages = 40–48 | doi = 10.1016/j.spacepol.2012.11.006 | arxiv = 1207.5540 }} In 2015, [[João Pedro de Magalhães]] proposed transmitting an invitation message to any extraterrestrial intelligences watching us already in the context of the [[Zoo Hypothesis]] and inviting them to respond. By using existing television and radio channels, de Magalhães argued this would not put us in any danger, "at least not in any more danger than we are already if much more advanced extraterrestrial civilizations are aware of us and can reach the solar system." {{cite journal |last=de Magalhaes |first=J. P. |arxiv=1509.03652 |title=A direct communication proposal to test the Zoo Hypothesis |date=2015 |doi=10.1016/j.spacepol.2016.06.001 |volume=38 |journal=Space Policy |pages=22–26}} [[Douglas Vakoch]], president of METI, argues that passive SETI itself is already an endorsement of active SETI, since "If we detect a signal from aliens through a SETI program, there’s no way to prevent a cacophony of responses from Earth."{{Cite news |author=Hannah Osborne |url=http://www.newsweek.com/advanced-alien-civilization-send-messages-meti-713186 |title=Scientists Have Sent Messages to Advanced Alien Civilizations—And Are Hoping for a Reply in 25 Years |date=2017-11-16 |work=Newsweek |access-date=2017-11-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117024323/http://www.newsweek.com/advanced-alien-civilization-send-messages-meti-713186 |archivedate=2017-11-17|df=}} ==Beacon proposals== One proposal for a 10 billion watt interstellar SETI beacon was dismissed by [[Robert A. Freitas Jr.]] to be infeasible for a pre-Type I civilization on the [[Kardashev scale]]. {{cite journal |last = Freitas |first = R. A. |year = 1980 |title = Interstellar Probes: A new approach to SETI |url = http://www.rfreitas.com/Astro/InterstellarProbesJBIS1980.htm |journal = Journal of the British Interplanetary Society |volume = 33 |issue = |pages = 95–100 |bibcode = 1980JBIS...33...95F |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160414033819/http://www.rfreitas.com/Astro/InterstellarProbesJBIS1980.htm |archivedate = 2016-04-14 |df = }} However, this 1980s technical argument assumes omni-directional beacons which may not be the best way to proceed on many technical grounds. Advances in consumer electronics have made possible transmitters that simultaneously transmit many narrow beams, covering the million or so nearest stars but not the spaces between. {{cite journal |last1=Scheffer |first1=L. K. |year=2005 |title=A scheme for a high-power, low-cost transmitter for deep space applications |journal=Radio Science |volume=40 |issue=5 |pages=RS5012 |bibcode = 2005RaSc...40.5012S |doi=10.1029/2005RS003243 |citeseerx=10.1.1.585.9519 }} This multibeam approach can reduce the power and cost to levels that are reasonable with current mid-2000s Earth technology. Once civilizations have discovered each other's locations, the energy requirements for maintaining contact and exchanging information can be significantly reduced through the use of highly directional transmission technologies. A 2018 study estimated an 1 to 2 megawatt infrared laser focused through a 30 to 45 meter telescope could be seen from about 20,000 light years away.[https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2018/11/08/magnified-laser-from-earth-could-attract-alien-attention-mit-researcher-says/HrbyazamrVaQ1NaBJhdllJ/story.html Magnified laser from Earth could attract alien attention, MIT researcher says] ==See also== * [[SETIcon]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.cplire.ru/html/ra&sr/irm/index.html Interstellar Radio Messages] * [http://www.activeseti.org ActiveSETI.org] * [http://active-seti.info/ active-seti.info] * [http://www.setileague.org/editor/meti.htm Making a Case for METI] * [https://www.fourmilab.ch/goldberg/setimsg.html Self-Decoding Messages] * [http://www.starshipnivan.com/blog/?p=65 Should We Shout Into the Darkness?] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110605025707/http://www3.sympatico.ca/stephane_dumas/CETI/dutil_dumas.pdf Error Correction Schemes In Active SETI] * [http://activeseti.org/papers/evpatoria07.pdf The Evpatoria Messages] * [http://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/E/Encounter2001.html Encounter 2001 Message] * [https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-13196-7_21 METI: Messaging to Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence] * [http://www.centauri-dreams.org/?p=17861 The Pros and Cons of METI from Centauri Dreams] * [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0094576511001652 Classification of interstellar radio messages] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130707124938/http://www.lonesignal.com/ Lone Signal] {{Extraterrestrial life}} {{Interstellar messages}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Active Seti}} [[Category:Search for extraterrestrial intelligence|*]] [[Category:Interstellar messages|*]] [[Category:Technology in society]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} The '''African Writers' Evening''' is the first regular evening held for African writers at the UK's Poetry Café. It was started in 2003 by [[Nii Ayikwei Parkes]] in consultation with the directors of the [[Poetry Society]]{{cite web|url=http://www.x-bout.com/awe/?page_id=2|title=African Writers Evening » About|accessdate=28 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100926110840/http://www.x-bout.com/awe/?page_id=2| archivedate= 26 September 2010 | deadurl= no}} after he completed a residency there. The solid reputation of African Writers' Evening is based on its ability to consistently identify and feature talented emerging writers. Diana Evans and [[Hisham Matar]], for example, were both featured prior to the official releases of their début publications, two of 2007′s features Ken Kamoche and [[Sade Adeniran]] were shortlisted for the 2008 [[Commonwealth Prize]] for their first books, and [[Inua Ellams]] won an [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] First Award three years after his first featured appearance at African Writers' Evening in 2006. Recently, the event's founder Nii Ayikwei Parkes was himself shortlisted for the Commonwealth Prize and the November 2009 featured reader, [[Nadifa Mohamed]] won the 2010 [[Betty Trask Award]]. African Writers' Evening is held bi-monthly from March to November with occasional special events, such as the AWE Heritage Series launched at the [[Southbank Centre]] on 6 July 2009 and AWE/NYC, which was held at the Bowery Club in September 2009. While the event is still held mainly at the Poetry Café in [[Covent Garden]], a recent partnership with the [[Southbank Centre]] has seen the end-of-year reading in November held at the [[Royal Festival Hall]] since 2008. ==Policy== African Writers' Evening features writers of all genres and defines "African" based on lived experience rather than simplistic notions of heritage. Featured writers have included white writers like [[Robyn Scott]], [[Isobel Dixon]] and [[Gillian Slovo]], as well as Africans of Indian origin such as Sharmila Chauhan. ==First event== The first African Writers' Evening was held in July 2003 at the Poetry Café and featured Nii Ayikwei Parkes (who was writer-in-residence at the venue), [[Jessica Horn]], a Ugandan poet, and Abby Ajayi, a Nigerian-British short story and script writer. The event in its current format started in July 2004. Its tagline is: ''Where Africa speaks and the world listens''. ==History and expansion== African Writers' Evening initially paid writers travel expenses and they read for free as a way of supporting the reading series. However, in September 2005, the series received funding from the [[Arts Council England|Arts Council of England]] and began to pay the featured writers an appearance fee. This development allowed the series to begin flying writers in from abroad to share their work: [[Helon Habila]]'s appearance at the Royal Festival Hall in 2009 was part of this trend. Since the New York event held in September 2009, African Writers' Evening appears to be on a path of expansion and collaboration. In April 2010, they held an event in Birmingham in collaboration with The Drum Theatre, the [[British Council]] and London Book Festival and in July 2010 a book sale event, named the African Book Market was held at the Poetry Café in partnership with major publishers, such as [[Random House]], as well as smaller outfits like [[Serpent's Tail]]. They also announced a book discussion initiative starting in September 2010. ==Organisation== The event is run by a London-based collective called London Society, Literature, Arts and Music Central, abbreviated as London SLAM Central. ==List of previous featured readers== {| class="wikitable" !Year !Month !Featured author(s) !Host !Venue |- |rowspan=3|'''2004''' |July |Open Mike |[[Nii Ayikwei Parkes]] |Poetry Café |- |September |Leeto Thale (South Africa) |Nii Ayikwei Parkes |Poetry Café |- |November |Open Mike |Nii Ayikwei Parkes |Poetry Café |- |rowspan=5|'''2005''' |March |[[Valerie Mason-John]] (Sierra Leone)

[[File:Artamus cyanopterus Mortimer.jpg|thumb|[[Dusky woodswallow]] (''Artamus cyanopterus'') parent feeding a [[wasp]] to chicks]]
'''Allofeeding''' is a type of [[Evolutionary models of food sharing|food sharing]] [[Behavior|behaviour]] observed in [[Cooperative breeding|cooperatively breed]]ing species of [[bird]]s. Allofeeding refers to a parent, sibling or unrelated adult bird feeding [[altricial]] [[hatchling]]s, which are dependent on [[parental care]] for their survival.<ref name="barrows">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=yaXMBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA13&dq=evolution+of+allofeeding&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjE9ePx_sHRAhWLq1QKHUJ1CC8Q6AEINjAF#v=onepage&q=evolution%20of%20allofeeding&f=false|title=Animal Behavior Desk Reference|last=Barrows|first=Edward M.|publisher=CRC Press|year=2011|isbn=978-1-4398-3652-1|edition=3rd|location=Boca Raton, FL}}</ref> Allofeeding also refers to food sharing between adults of the same species.<ref name="handicap">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=ImjqhNqjiqsC&pg=PA137&dq=evolution+of+allofeeding&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-jfi2gMLRAhVIhlQKHVOQAHE4ChDoAQgfMAE#v=onepage&q=evolution%20of%20allofeeding&f=false|title=The Handicap Principle: A Missing Piece of Darwin's Puzzle|last1=Zahavi|first1=Amotz|last2=Zahavi|first2=Avishag|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=1997|isbn=0-19-510035-2}}</ref> Allofeeding can occur between mates during mating rituals, [[Courtship display|courtship]], egg laying or incubation, between peers of the same species, or as a form of parental care.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=Susan M.|date=1980|title=Demand Behavior: A New Interpretation of Courtship Feeding|jstor=1367395|journal=The Condor|volume=82|issue=3|pages=291–295|doi=10.2307/1367395}}</ref><ref name=":33">{{Cite journal|last=Halley|first=Matthew R.|last2=Holmes|first2=Aaron L.|last3=Robinson|first3=W. Douglas|date=2015-06-01|title=Biparental incubation and allofeeding at nests of Sagebrush Brewer's Sparrows|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jofo.12098/abstract|journal=Journal of Field Ornithology|language=en|volume=86|issue=2|pages=153–162|doi=10.1111/jofo.12098|issn=1557-9263}}</ref>
Allofeeding evolved for different reasons in different species of birds. While Sagebrush Brewer’s Sparrows allofeed to reduce [[predation]] during incubation, Sichuan Jays allofeed to increase a female’s nutritional level prior to egg laying, and Chinstrap Penguins allofeed to strengthen the bond between the pair during chick guarding.<ref name=":33" /><ref name=":44">{{Cite journal|last=Jing|first=Yu|last2=Fang|first2=Yun|last3=Strickland|first3=Dan|last4=Lu|first4=Nan|last5=Sun|first5=Yue-Hua|date=2009|title=Alloparenting in the Rare Sichuan Jay (Perisoreus Internigrans) - Cuidado Aloparental en la Especie Rara Perisoreus internigrans|journal=The Condor|volume=111|issue=4|pages=662–667|doi=10.1525/cond.2009.080114|jstor=10.1525/cond.2009.080114}}</ref><ref name=":54">{{Cite journal|last=Mori|first=Yoshihisa|last2=Kokubun|first2=Nobuo|last3=Shin|first3=Hyoung-Chul|last4=Takahashi|first4=Akinori|date=2010-10-01|title=An observation of between-mates feeding behaviour in chick-guarding chinstrap penguins|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00300-010-0842-8|journal=Polar Biology|language=en|volume=33|issue=10|pages=1437–1438|doi=10.1007/s00300-010-0842-8|issn=0722-4060}}</ref>
While parental allofeeding is a common form of parental care among many species of birds, the practice is not inherently restricted to biological parents and their young, and is often done for reasons unrelated to the well-being of the chicks. Arabian Bablers, for instance, peer allofeed in an attempt at increasing their social rank, whereas the King Penguin considers those 'non-breeders' who allofeed chicks to be altruistic and highly revered. And the far more practical Barn Owl, of course, peer allofeeds merely to reduce sibling rivalry/competition during meal times.<ref name=":03">{{Cite journal|last=Carlisle|first=Tamsie R.|last2=Zahavi|first2=Amotz|date=1986-04-01|title=Helping at the nest, allofeeding and social status in immature arabian babblers|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00299665|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|language=en|volume=18|issue=5|pages=339–351|doi=10.1007/BF00299665|issn=0340-5443}}</ref><ref name=":63">{{Cite journal|last=Roulin|first=A.|last2=Monstiers|first2=B. Des|last3=Ifrid|first3=E.|last4=Silva|first4=A. Da|last5=Genzoni|first5=E.|last6=Dreiss|first6=A. N.|date=2016-02-01|title=Reciprocal preening and food sharing in colour-polymorphic nestling barn owls|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/jeb.12793|journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology|language=en|volume=29|issue=2|pages=380–394|doi=10.1111/jeb.12793|issn=1420-9101}}</ref>
Although many species of birds exhibit allofeeding, there are some species that do not perform allofeeding, such as Siberian Jays.<ref name=":44" />
== Allofeeding between mates == Many species of migratory [[songbird]]s display allofeeding during the [[incubation period]].<ref name=":33" /> During the incubation period, a male songbird will feed its mate, while she sits on the eggs through beak-to-beak interaction.<ref name=":33" /> This allofeeding behaviour is suggested to be adaptive because the male is indirectly investing in its offspring.<ref name=":33" /> The male uses its energy to forage and retrieve food, and to feed the female.<ref name=":33" /> This behaviour of the male reduces nutritional stress of the female because it reduces the amount of time the female spends foraging.<ref name=":33" /> In addition, the allofeeding behaviour decreases the number of times a female has to leave the nest, which in turn extends the incubation period and reduces the risk of nest being detected by a predator.<ref name=":33" /> Overall, allofeeding behaviour contributes to increased fitness and is therefore considered advantageous.<ref name=":33" /> However, Nolan (1958) theorizes that allofeeding is a non-adaptive and is derived from anticipatory parental care.<ref name=":33" />
Allofeeding during the incubation period can also transpire through both the male and the female interchangeably feeding each other via beak-to-beak interactions, while a mate receiving the food incubates the eggs.<ref name=":33" /> Once feeding is completed, the recipient now becomes the feeder and the mate that was just foraging incubates the eggs. For example, Sagebrush Brewer’s Sparrows (''Spizella breweri breweri'') allofeed in this manner.<ref name=":33" /> A recent study by Halley et al., 2015, examined allofeeding in twenty-four nests of Sagebrush Brewer’s Sparrows.<ref name=":33" /> This study revealed that allofeeding occurred at low frequencies (55%) in nests with biparental incubation and no allofeeding occurred in uniparental nests.<ref name=":33" /> This study suggests that allofeeding is an intraspecific signal required to maintain social bonds between mates, in addition to increasing the nutrition levels of females and concealment of the nest.<ref name=":33" /> Furthermore, the study found that incubation sessions per hour were higher in biparental nests with allofeeding than in biparental nests without allofeeding.<ref name=":33" /> These findings indicate that allofeeding is beneficial because it reduces the risk of predation from visually oriented predators through increased nest concealment,<ref name=":33" /> which can maximize the fitness of males while increasing the fitness of females.<ref name=":33" />
There have been many documented observations of allofeeding between mates (mate allofeeding).<ref name=":54" /> However, in penguins allofeeding between mates is rare.<ref name=":54" /> In 2010, [[Chinstrap penguin|Chinstrap Penguins]] (''P. antarctica'') allofeeding was reported during the period of chick guarding.<ref name=":54" /> The researchers witnessed a male feeding a female, which had a large chick in its nest.<ref name=":54" /> The behaviour was engaged by the female frequently pecking the side of the male’s bill to stimulate the male to regurgitate its food.<ref name=":54" /> This resulted in the male regurgitating its food into the female’s open mouth. This allofeeding behaviour was identical to the manner in which a chick begs its parent for food.<ref name=":54" /> Notably, during this behaviour the female kept the attention of male when the chick tried to gain the male’s attention.<ref name=":54" /> It is proposed that mate allofeeding in Chinstrap Penguins was performed to strengthen the bond between the pair.<ref name=":54" />
Allofeeding between mates can also occur during courtship.<ref name=":54" /> Courtship allofeeding occurs in half of bird subfamilies and mainly appears in monogamous bird species.<ref name=":54" /> Courtship allofeeding is hypothesized to strengthen the bond between pairs or increase a female’s nutritional level before laying eggs.<ref name=":54" /> For example, in the Sichuan Jay ([[Sichuan jay|''P. internigrans'']]), females are fed by only one male during courtship.<ref name=":44" /> It is suggested that allofeeding the female during courtship, increases a female’s nutritional level before egg laying.<ref name=":44" /> This behaviour was also recorded in the Grey Jays (''[[Grey jay|P. canadensis]]'').<ref name=":44" /> Other species of birds display allofeeding during courtship. Additionally, courtship allofeeding in some birds species is hypothesized to strengthen the bond between pairs.<ref name=":54" />
== Allofeeding and parental care ==
=== ''Aptenodytes patagonicus'' === [[File:Emperor-feeding_hg.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Emperor-feeding_hg.jpg|thumb|Emperor Penguin (''Aptenodytes patagonicus)'' feeding its offspring]] A parent feeding a non-biological chick via bill-to-bill interactions is a form of allofeeding.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Lecomte|first=Nicolas|last2=Kuntz|first2=Gregoire|last3=Lambert|first3=Nicolas|last4=Gendner|first4=Jean-Paul|last5=Handrich|first5=Yves|last6=Maho|first6=Yvon Le|last7=Bost|first7=Charles-André|title=Alloparental feeding in the king penguin|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0003347205004173|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=71|issue=2|pages=457–462|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2005.07.007}}</ref><ref name=":23">{{Cite journal|last=Jouventin|first=Pierre|last2=Barbraud|first2=Christophe|last3=Rubin|first3=Michel|title=Adoption in the emperor penguin, Aptenodytes forsteri|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/0003-3472(95)80102-2|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=50|issue=4|pages=1023–1029|doi=10.1016/0003-3472(95)80102-2}}</ref> Parental allofeeding occurs in all altricial species of birds to ensure proper growth, development, and to prevent starvation of their offspring.<ref name=":113">{{Cite journal|last=Eggers|first=Sönke|last2=Griesser|first2=Michael|last3=Ekman|first3=Jan|date=2005-01-01|title=Predator-induced plasticity in nest visitation rates in the Siberian jay (Perisoreus infaustus)|url=http://academic.oup.com/beheco/article/16/1/309/206728/Predatorinduced-plasticity-in-nest-visitation|journal=Behavioral Ecology|language=en|volume=16|issue=1|pages=309–315|doi=10.1093/beheco/arh163|issn=1045-2249}}</ref> This form of allofeeding has been shown to be a form of parental care in some species, such as in King Penguins ([[King penguin|''A. patagonicus'']]).<ref name=":13" /> King Penguins are pelagic seabirds.<ref name=":13" /> King Penguin chicks form dense groups called crèches during winter for social thermoregulation when food availability is low.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":23" /> The formation of crèches results from the parents interchangeably leaving starving chicks to gather food from the sea.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":23" /> A study by Lecomte et al., 2015 examined the allofeeding behaviour in King Penguins, in which they marked the white underbellies of 74 non-breeding adults and 103 breeding pairs with a unique dark colouring called dye-mark code of Nyanzol-D.<ref name=":13" /> Lecomte et al. (2015) found 22% of the marked adults feed 65% of the chicks in crèches, revealing that allofeeding behaviour was most common during the breeding season.<ref name=":13" /> Lecomte et al. (2015) also identified that most of the 22% of adult King Penguins demonstrating allofeeding behaviour were unable to successfully breed along with few breeders performing the behaviour.<ref name=":13" /> The allofeeding behaviour resulted in more feedings for chicks,<ref name=":13" /> which is consistent with study by Pierre et al. (1994) that showed that allofeeding in penguins increases the chick growth rate from 35g/day to 190g/day.<ref name=":23" /> From these results, Lecomte et al., (2015) concluded that allofeeding increased the survival rate of chicks in crèches.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":23" /> The results imply that parental allofeeding in King Penguins is an altruistic behaviour, where allofeeding benefits the young at a cost to the non-biological parent.<ref name=":13" /> Notably, no direct benefits to the non-biological parents have been described.<ref name=":13" /> The cost of allofeeding non-biological chicks resulted in no detrimental effects to the fitness of the [[Alloparenting|alloparent]], because the cost of allofeeding is low (several grams) when compared to the nutritional costs of an adult king penguin, which is several kilograms.<ref name=":13" /> However, it is suggested that allofeeding many chicks may cost each chick lost meals that can cause negative effects on the fitness of allofed chicks.<ref name=":13" /> In addition, allofeeding decreases when non-biological parents had offspring.<ref name=":13" />
=== ''Pseudomonas antarctica'' === The [[Chinstrap penguin|Chinstrap Penguin]] (''P. antarctica'') is another species of penguin that displays allofeeding.<ref name=":54" /> Allofeeding in the Chinstrap Penguin has been observed between the female and its offspring.<ref name=":54" /> Similar to mate allofeeding in this species, the offspring of a female will peck the side of the female’s bill to signal the female to regurgitate its food into the chick's open mouth.<ref name=":54" />
=== ''Perisoreus internigrans'' === In Sichuan Jays ([[Sichuan jay|''P. Internigrans'']]), females are not the only sex that participates in the allofeeding of their offspring.<ref name=":44" /> During their first week of life, the chicks are only fed by the male.<ref name=":73">{{Cite news|url=https://britishbirds.co.uk/article/studies-of-less-familiar-birds-162-siberian-jay/|title=Studies of less Familiar birds 162 Siberian Jay - British Birds|last=Blomgren|first=Arne Blomgren|date=|work=British Birds|access-date=2018-03-12|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> The male forages and stores food in a pouch within its throat. At the nest, the male regurgitates the semi-digested food from its pouch into the mouths of its chicks.<ref name=":73" /> After the first week, the male continues to feed the chicks while the female begins feeding the chicks.<ref name=":44" /> The female uses the same method as the male.<ref name=":73" />
== Peer allofeeding ==
=== ''Turdoides sqamiceps'' === There have been many reported cases of allofeeding between siblings in several species of birds.<ref name=":03" /> For example, the Arabian Babblers ([[Arabian babbler|''T. sqamiceps'']]) are a territorial, desert inhibiting species of bird that participate in cooperative breeding.<ref name=":03" /> In this species, non-breeders show numerous types of cooperative behaviour, including allofeeding.<ref name=":03" /> Adult and immature Babblers, as well as previous and newly fledged Babblers, will frequently engage in allofeeding behaviour.<ref name=":03" />
Carlisle et al. (1986) revealed that Arabian Babblers participate in peer allofeeding in order to increase social rank, which increases fitness.<ref name=":03" /> This allofeeding behaviour is supported by the Zahavi's hypothesis.<ref name=":03" /> An individual (a dominate Babbler) can increase in social rank by allofed a subordinate Babbler.<ref name=":03" /> On the contrary, an individual (a subordinate Babbler) can decrease in social rank when they are allofed by a dominate Babbler.<ref name=":03" /> Subordinate Babblers have been observed refusing to be allofeed by dominate Babbler.<ref name=":03" /> The refusal resulted in the dominate Babbler becoming aggressive with the subordinate - hitting or chasing the subordinate.<ref name=":03" /> Dominate Babblers also showed the same aggressive behaviours when a subordinate tried to allofeed it.<ref name=":03" />
=== ''Tyto alba'' === Another species that exhibits peer allofeeding is the [[Barn owl|Barn Owl]] (''T. alba'').<ref name=":63" /> Barn Owl nest siblings establish a hierarchy for the sharing of food resources via vocal negotiations.<ref name=":63" /> It is suggested that Barn Owl nest siblings show peer allofeeding to reduce sibling competition in the food sharing hierarchy.<ref name=":63" /> Peer allofeeding observed in 60 nestling pairs revealed that the behaviour occurs by a donor sibling placing the food item on the ground in front of the receiver sibling, which transfers the food item to its bill using its talons.<ref name=":63" /> Alternatively, the donor sibling uses its bill to place the food item in the bill of the receiver sibling.<ref name=":63" /> As well, peer allofeeding behaviour in Barn Owl siblings is proposed to increase the [[inclusive fitness]] of the peer performing the allofeeding.<ref name=":63" />
== Intraspecific allofeeding ==
=== ''Perisoreus Internigrans'' === [[File:Perisoreus_canadensis_feeding_at_nest.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Perisoreus_canadensis_feeding_at_nest.jpg|thumb|Gray Jays (''Perisoreus canadensis)'' feeding offspring at the nest]] Intraspecific allofeeding in Sichuan Jays (''[[Sichuan jay|P. internigrans]]'') is performed during the nestling and fledging period by non-breeders.<ref name=":44" /> One to three non-breeders support a nesting breeding pair by feeding the chicks, regurgitating the food from their throat pouches.<ref name=":44" /><ref name=":73" /> In 2009, Jing et al. determined that two non-breeders contributed to 44% of feedings in the nest of two Sichuan Jays.<ref name=":44" /> Jing et al. (2009) suggest that allofeeding behaviour contributes to increased nest survival.<ref name=":44" />
In Sichuan Jays, allofeeding is hypothesized to be evolutionary selected.<ref name=":44" /> In this species, two to three non-breeders will allofeed the young of a breeding pair.<ref name=":44" /> The large body mass (21% heavier than Siberian Jays) of the Sichuan Jays, and the presence of more than one non-breeder, allows one non-breeder to ward off a predator while another non-breeder protects the young from additional predators.<ref name=":44" /> Both the large body mass of the non-breeders and the presence of multiple non-breeders reduces the risk of injury or death when predators are encountered.<ref name=":44" /> This reveals that the benefits of allofeeding the young outweighs the cost of injury or death of the non-breeder and/or chick when more than one non-breeder is present.<ref name=":44" /> Peer allofeeding has also been observed in the Gray Jay (''[[Grey jay|P. canadensis]]'').<ref name=":44" /> In the Gray Jay, non-breeders allofeed the young after fledging.<ref name=":44" />
Not all species of jays allofeed their young, such as the Siberian Jay (''[[Siberian jay|P. infaustus]]'').<ref name=":44" /> In the Siberian Jays, non-breeders do not allofeed the chicks of a breeding pair.<ref name=":44" /> It is predicted that Siberian Jays do not display allofeeding because the cost of predation is too high.<ref name=":44" /> Siberian Jays are continuously threatened by a more dangerous predators, the Eurasian Sparrowhawk and Northern Goshawk, then Gray Jays, which are threatened by Eurasian red squirrel.<ref name=":44" /> One non-breeder per breeding pair and the small size (21% less body mass than the Sichuan Jays) of the Siberian Jays, in combination with continuous risk of predation, reveals that the non-breeding Siberian Jays are unable to confront predators and protect the nest simultaneously.<ref name=":44" /> This indicates that the cost of allofeeding the young is more costly to the non-breeder when one non-breeder is present because an encounter with a predator increases the risk of injury and death of both the young and the non-breeder.<ref name=":44" /> This reveals that the benefit of allofeeding the young does not exceed the cost of injury or death of non-breeder and/or young.<ref name=":44" /> This is consistent with the predator-avoidance hypothesis, suggesting that the cost of allofeeding in the Siberian Jays prevents allofeeding from being evolutionary selected.<ref name=":44" />
